relics.name: Dog-eared TG-51 Protocol
relics.description: This well-used protocol guide has seen better days, but the knowledge remains.

content.question: If a radioisotope has a half-life of 8 days, approximately what fraction of the original activity will remain after 24 days?
content.explanation: After 24 days (3 half-lives), the remaining activity is (1/2)³ = 1/8 of the original activity.

content.title: Reference Material
content.text: You study important concepts in your textbook.

content.question: What is the typical slice thickness used in CT simulation for radiotherapy planning?
content.explanation: Typical slice thickness for CT simulation in radiotherapy planning is 2-3 mm, balancing spatial resolution with imaging dose and data size.

content.question: According to regulatory requirements, how often must a linear accelerator's calibration be verified?
content.explanation: Daily output constancy checks are required by regulatory agencies to ensure that the linear accelerator's calibration remains within acceptable limits.

content.question: What is the annual effective dose limit for radiation workers?
content.explanation: The annual effective dose limit for radiation workers is 20 mSv averaged over 5 years, with no single year exceeding 50 mSv.

content.question: What is the typical slice thickness used in CT simulation for radiotherapy planning?
content.explanation: Typical slice thickness for CT simulation in radiotherapy planning is 2-3 mm, balancing spatial resolution with imaging dose and data size.

content.question: Which organization is responsible for accrediting radiation oncology practices in the United States?
content.explanation: The American College of Radiology (ACR) provides accreditation for radiation oncology practices, though other organizations like ASTRO also offer accreditation programs.

content.question: Which organization is responsible for accrediting radiation oncology practices in the United States?
content.explanation: The American College of Radiology (ACR) provides accreditation for radiation oncology practices, though other organizations like ASTRO also offer accreditation programs.

content.question: Which of the following chambers is typically used for reference dosimetry in external beam radiotherapy?
content.explanation: Farmer-type cylindrical chambers are commonly used for reference dosimetry in external beam radiotherapy due to their stability and well-characterized response.

content.title: Reference Material
content.text: You study important concepts in your textbook.

content.question: What is the frequency of full calibration required after a source exchange for an HDR unit?
options: Immediately before the first patient treatment
Within 24 hours before the first patient treatment
Within 7 days before the first patient treatment
Within 30 days before the first patient treatment
content.explanation: A full calibration of an HDR unit is required immediately before the first patient treatment following a source exchange.

content.title: Break Room
content.text: You take a moment to rest and recover.

content.title: Rotation Evaluation
content.text: Your knowledge is being tested as part of your rotation evaluation.

questions.question: What is the typical slice thickness used in CT simulation for radiotherapy planning?
questions.explanation: Typical slice thickness for CT simulation in radiotherapy planning is 2-3 mm, balancing spatial resolution with imaging dose and data size.

questions.question: A Winston-Lutz test is primarily used to verify what parameter?
questions.explanation: The Winston-Lutz test is used to verify the coincidence of the radiation isocenter with the mechanical isocenter of the treatment machine.

questions.question: Which of the following optimization objectives would be LEAST appropriate for a prostate IMRT plan?
options: Maximize target coverage with 95% of prescription dose
Minimize femoral head maximum dose to <45 Gy
Maximize dose conformity to femoral heads
questions.explanation: Maximizing dose conformity to femoral heads would be inappropriate as the femoral heads are critical structures to avoid, not targets for dose delivery.

content.question: Which of the following parameters is NOT directly adjusted by the automatic exposure control (AEC) in a CT scanner?
content.explanation: Automatic exposure control (AEC) in CT primarily modulates the tube current (mA) based on patient attenuation to maintain image quality. Rotation time is typically set manually.

content.question: Which of the following parameters is NOT directly adjusted by the automatic exposure control (AEC) in a CT scanner?
content.explanation: Automatic exposure control (AEC) in CT primarily modulates the tube current (mA) based on patient attenuation to maintain image quality. Rotation time is typically set manually.

content.question: What is the frequency of full calibration required after a source exchange for an HDR unit?
options: Immediately before the first patient treatment
Within 24 hours before the first patient treatment
Within 7 days before the first patient treatment
Within 30 days before the first patient treatment
content.explanation: A full calibration of an HDR unit is required immediately before the first patient treatment following a source exchange.

content.title: Conference
content.text: You attend a conference and make valuable connections.

content.question: In inverse planning for IMRT, what is typically specified as part of the optimization objectives?
options: The number of monitor units per segment
Dose-volume constraints for targets and organs at risk
content.explanation: In inverse planning for IMRT, dose-volume constraints (or objectives) for targets and organs at risk are specified, and the treatment planning system optimizes the fluence patterns to meet these objectives.

content.question: Using the inverse square law, if the dose rate at 100 cm from a source is 2.0 Gy/min, what would be the dose rate at 50 cm?
content.explanation: According to the inverse square law, the dose rate varies inversely with the square of the distance. So, 2.0 Gy/min × (100/50)² = 2.0 Gy/min × 4 = 8.0 Gy/min.

content.title: Complex Case
content.text: You face a particularly challenging clinical scenario.

questions.question: According to TG-218, what is the recommended gamma criteria for IMRT/VMAT patient-specific QA?
questions.explanation: TG-218 recommends a gamma criteria of 3%/3mm with a 95% passing rate, but also notes that each clinic should establish its own action levels based on their specific equipment and procedures.

questions.question: Which of the following optimization objectives would be LEAST appropriate for a prostate IMRT plan?
options: Maximize target coverage with 95% of prescription dose
Minimize femoral head maximum dose to <45 Gy
Maximize dose conformity to femoral heads
questions.explanation: Maximizing dose conformity to femoral heads would be inappropriate as the femoral heads are critical structures to avoid, not targets for dose delivery.

content.title: Reference Material
content.text: You study important concepts in your textbook.

content.question: Which of the following optimization objectives would be LEAST appropriate for a prostate IMRT plan?
options: Maximize target coverage with 95% of prescription dose
Minimize femoral head maximum dose to <45 Gy
Maximize dose conformity to femoral heads
content.explanation: Maximizing dose conformity to femoral heads would be inappropriate as the femoral heads are critical structures to avoid, not targets for dose delivery.

content.question: According to TG-100, what is the primary method recommended for identifying potential failure modes in a radiotherapy process?
content.explanation: TG-100 recommends Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (FMEA) as the primary method for proactively identifying potential failure modes in radiotherapy processes.

content.question: A patient is prescribed 50 Gy in 25 fractions with an α/β ratio of 3 Gy for late effects. What is the equivalent dose in 2 Gy fractions (EQD2) for late effects?
content.explanation: Using the EQD2 formula: EQD2 = D × (d + (α/β)) / (2 + (α/β)), where D is the total dose, d is the dose per fraction, and α/β is the tissue-specific ratio. EQD2 = 50 × (2 + 3) / (2 + 3) = 50 Gy.

content.question: According to TG-100, what is the primary method recommended for identifying potential failure modes in a radiotherapy process?
content.explanation: TG-100 recommends Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (FMEA) as the primary method for proactively identifying potential failure modes in radiotherapy processes.
